clinicalAssessment.chiefComplaint: Persistent headaches and dizziness for 3 weeks
clinicalAssessment.historyOfPresentIllness: 44-year-old male presents with 3-week history of bilateral throbbing headaches, rated 7/10 on pain scale. Headaches occur daily, lasting 4-6 hours. Associated symptoms include nausea, photophobia, and occasional dizziness. No fever, neck stiffness, or focal neurological symptoms. No recent head trauma or travel history. OTC medications have provided no relief.

physicalExamination.general: Well-appearing, no acute distress, alert and oriented x3
physicalExamination.heent: Normocephalic, no meningeal signs, PERRLA, EOMI
physicalExamination.neurological: CN II-XII intact, no focal deficits, normal reflexes
physicalExamination.cardiovascular: RRR, no murmurs, no gallops, no rubs

assessment: Headaches - Likely tension type headaches, but neuroimaging indicated to rule out intracranial pathology
Hypertension - Well controlled on current medications
plan: Order MRI brain with contrast to rule out intracranial pathology
Consider neurology referral if MRI abnormal
Follow-up in 2 weeks with MRI results
Patient education regarding headache triggers and management
